citation.article-title: Rhizobium lusitanum sp. nov. a bacterium that nodulates Phaseolus vulgaris
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Rhizobium lusitanum sp. nov.
Rhizobium lusitanum (lu.si.ta′num. L. neut. adj. lusitanum of Lusitania, the Roman name of Portugal, where the strains reported in this study were isolated).
Gram-negative rods, as for the other species of the genus.
Colonies are small, pearl white on YMA at 28 °C, which is the optimal growth temperature.
Strains may grow between 10 and 37 °C, pH 5 and 8 and weakly up to 1 % (w/v) NaCl.
Denitrification is carried out by the strains from this study.
The strains produce β-galactosidase and urease and hydrolyse aesculin in the API 20NE system.

They also produce α- and β-arabinosidases, α- and β-galactosidases, β-galactosidaminidases, β-cellobiases, α- and β-xylosidases, α-maltosidases and β-glucosaminidases using chromogenic p-nitrophenyl substrates.
They do not produce indole, arginine dihydrolase or gelatinase in API 20NE.

They use glucose, melezitose, ethanol, meso-erythritol, l-arabinose, mannose, fructose, galactose, l-rhamnose, xylose, N-acetylglucosamine, maltose, sucrose, cellobiose, raffinose, melibiose, trehalose, salicin, inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, malate, gluconate and citrate as carbon sources.
They grow on l-histidine, aspartate, glutamate and betaine as carbon and nitrogen sources.
They grow weakly on l-lysine, xylitol and l-sorbose.
They do not grow on caprate, adipate, phenylacetate, glucuronate, propionate, valine or l-alanine.
All strains are resistant to ampicillin, erythromycin, cloxacillin, penicillin, cefuroxime and oxytetracycline.
They do not grow in the presence of ciprofloxacin, polymyxin B or gentamicin.
Growth is weak in the presence of neomycin.
The G+C content of strain P1-7T is 65.15 mol%.
The type strain, P1-7T (=LMG 22705T=CECT 7016T), was isolated from effective nodules of Phaseolus vulgaris in Portugal.
